title: How to Make Pavlova

parts.name: Making the Meringue for the Base

steps.headline: Assemble the ingredients.
steps.description: Pavlova has very few ingredients, but each one is very important. Don't make substitutions for any of the ingredients, since the texture of the dessert depends on the precise chemistry of each one.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 275 °F (135 °C).
steps.description: Arrange a rack in the lower third of the oven.

steps.headline: Prepare a baking sheet.
steps.description: Tear off a large sheet of parchment paper and place it on a baking sheet. Trace around the bottom of a 9-inch cake pan to draw a circle on the parchment paper. You'll spread the meringue mixture inside the circle to bake it.

steps.headline: Mix the sugar and cornstarch in a small bowl.
steps.description: If you'd like, add a pinch of salt as well.

steps.headline: Separate the egg whites from the yolks.
steps.description: It's very important to make sure the egg whites don't get tainted by bits of yolk; this will prevent your meringue from stiffening. Make sure you pour the whites into a very clean, dry metal mixing bowl. Water or bits of oil will affect the texture of your meringue. Keep the yolks for a different recipe, or make an omelette later.

steps.headline: Beat the egg whites.
steps.description: Use with a hand mixer on high speed for about 5 minutes, or beat with an egg whisk, until soft peaks form.

steps.headline: Add the castor sugar mixture by the teaspoonful.
steps.description: Keep beating the egg whites and add the sugar mixture teaspoon by teaspoon. Continue until you run out of sugar and the whites have formed stiff, glossy peaks.

steps.headline: Add the vinegar and vanilla.
steps.description: Pour the vinegar and vanilla over the peaks and keep beating until everything is mixed together. The vinegar will help the meringue stay crispy around the edges and soft in the middle as it bakes.

steps.headline: Spoon the mixture into the parchment circle.
steps.description: Use the back of the spoon to spread it evenly. It should be approximately dinner plate roundness in size.

steps.headline: Create a small indented hollow in the centre.
steps.description: Pavlovas should be round with a little hollow that takes the cream and topping, so it helps to imagine that you're making a nest shape with slightly raised edges. If your shape is on the oblong side of circular, don't worry too much about how accurate the circular shape is - creative misshapes are permissible as long as the topping stays put.

steps.headline: Bake the meringue.
steps.description: Place it in the oven and cook for 60-70 minutes, or until crisp. Don't let the meringue over-brown; it should be an off-white color on the outside when it's ready.

steps.headline: Remove the pavlova from the oven.
steps.description: Place it on a wire rack to cool. Transfer it to a serving dish and prepare to add the toppings. Allow the meringue to cool completely before finishing the dish. There's a tradition to turn the pavlova over and decorate the base because it is said that this side is less crisp. Sometimes this reason is actually a nifty cover-up trick for little cooking mistakes like over-browning the top. Either way, the pavlova centre will quickly lose its initial crispness anyway because of the whipped cream and topping.

parts.name: Finishing the Pavlova with the Topping

steps.headline: Prepare the toppings.
steps.description: Whip the cream and sugar until the cream forms soft peaks. Slice the strawberries and kiwis or other fruit toppings. If there's time left, research the origins of the pavlova and make up your own mind about who invented it.

steps.headline: Add the whipped cream.
steps.description: Spread it evenly to the edges of the meringue. Use the cream to fill in cracks and cover other imperfections. You can also flavor the cream if you'd like - try a teaspoon of vanilla extract, rosewater, orange water, lemon extract, or almond extract. Although whipped cream is traditional, you might like to vary the whipped cream with other soft creamy like substances such as custard. This would be frowned upon by traditionalists but experimental cooks have creative license.

steps.headline: Arrange the fruit on top.
steps.description: Lay the strawberry or kiwi slices in a pretty pattern over the whipped cream. Another popular tradition is to drizzle freshly opened passionfruit over the top of the pavlova. Other topping ideas include a mixture of berries, sliced cherries, apricots, mangoes or peaches,  grated dark chocolate, or a mixture of chocolate and raspberries.

steps.headline: Serve the pavlova.
steps.description: The beauty of a pavlova is in the eye of the creator; everyone else just wants to eat it. Don't be surprised at how quickly your creation disappears.
